title: 111_hr4235
content: The Act titled "Women's Hospitals Education Equity Act" amends the Public Health Service Act to support graduate medical education programs in women's hospitals. The Secretary will make two payments to women's hospitals for fiscal years 2010 through 2014 for direct and indirect expenses related to approved graduate medical residency training programs. Regulations will be established for these payments. The amounts payable for these programs will be determined based on direct expenses. The Secretary will make payments to women's hospitals for direct and indirect expenses associated with approved graduate medical residency training programs. The total payments in a fiscal year cannot exceed the appropriated funds. The Secretary will reduce payments to women's hospitals on a pro rata basis if funds are insufficient. Annual reporting provisions from section 340E apply to women's hospitals funded under this section. Interim payments will be determined by the Secretary. The Secretary determines interim payments for hospitals based on the number of residents reported in the hospital's Medicare cost report. Payments are made in 12 equal installments during the fiscal year. The Secretary determines interim payments for hospitals based on the number of residents trained during the hospital's most recent Medicare cost report filing period. Up to 25 percent may be withheld from each installment to prevent overpayment. At the end of each fiscal year, any changes in resident numbers are reconciled, and overpayments are recouped. The Secretary determines interim payments for hospitals based on resident training numbers from the most recent Medicare cost report filing period. Overpayments are recouped at the end of each fiscal year, with a final determination subject to review under the Social Security Act. Definitions for approved graduate medical residency training program and direct graduate medical education costs are provided. The term 'direct graduate medical education costs' is defined in section 1886(h)(5)(C) of the Social Security Act. A 'women's hospital' is a hospital with a Medicare provider agreement, an approved graduate medical residency training program, not excluded from the Medicare prospective payment system, had at least 3,000 births in 2007, and meets criteria set by the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services. According to the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, less than 4 percent of hospital discharges in 2007 were Medicare discharges of individuals enrolled in the original Medicare fee-for-service program under part A of title XVIII of the Social Security Act and not enrolled in a Medicare Advantage plan, an eligible organization, or a PACE program. Authorization of appropriations for section 1894 of the Act includes $12,000,000 for fiscal year 2010 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2011 through 2014.
